page.title: Abortion in Saint Kitts and Nevis

revision.comment: adding links
revision.text:
'''Abortion law in Saint Kitts and Nevis''', a country in the West Indies and a member of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]], is modelled on [[British legislation]]. [[Abortion]] is permitted in circumstances where a woman's life is threatened by pregnancy.
==Legislation== Abortion law in [[Saint Kitts and Nevis]], as in numerous other Commonwealth member countries, is based on the British [[Offences against the Person Act 1861]].<ref name=UN>{{cite book|title=Abortion Policies: A Global Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3iNmQIP7S2AC&pg=63|volume=3|year=2001|publisher=United Nations|isbn=978-92-1-151365-3|page=63}}</ref> Abortion is addressed in Part IX of Saint Kitts and Nevis's own Offences against the Person Act, in Sections 53 and 54, which state that any woman who unlawfully attempts to procure an abortion is guilty of [[felony]] and can be imprisoned for up to ten years with or without hard labour. A third party who administers an unlawful abortion is subject to the same penalty while the supplier of an instrument or substance with the knowledge that it will be used to cause an unlawful abortion is guilty of [[misdemeanour]] and faces a penalty of up to two years in prison.<ref name=harvard>{{cite web|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/population/abortion/Stkitts.abo.html|title=Saint Kitts and Nevis|publisher=[[Berkman Center for Internet & Society]], Harvard University|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
The Infant Life (Preservation) Act, which was adapted from the British [[Infant Life (Preservation) Act 1929]], permits abortion at any stage of pregnancy so long as the procedure is performed "in good faith for the purpose only of preserving the life of the mother". It states that a person who causes an abortion after 28 weeks of pregnancy is guilty of "child destruction", a felony, and is punishable with life imprisonment with or without hard labour.<ref name=harvard/> Saint Kitts and Nevis also follows precedents set in British abortion law, such as ''Rex v. [[Aleck Bourne|Bourne]]'' (1938), in which the court ruled that an abortion performed on a teenage rape victim was lawful as it prevented harm to the victim's physical and mental health.<ref name=UN/><ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.ceped.org/cdrom/avortement_ameriquelatine_2007/en/chapitre1/page3.html|publisher=CEPED|title=Abortion in Latin America and the Caribbean: A Review of the Literature from 1990 to 2005|chapter=Specific Characteristics of Abortion Legislation in Some Countries in the Region|year=2007|first1=Agnès|last1=Guillaume|first2=Susana|last2=Lerner|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
==Access to abortion services== A three-year study of abortion practices in the northeast Caribbean, published in 2005, noted that women from Saint Kitts and Nevis who are seeking abortions often travel to nearby Caribbean countries in order to remain anonymous.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pheterson|first1=G.|last2=Azize|first2=Y.|title=Abortion practice in the northeast Caribbean: "Just write down stomach pain" |journal=Reproductive Health Matters |volume=13 |issue=26 |pages=44–53 |year=2005 |pmid=16291485 |doi=10.1016/S0968-8080(05)26201-8}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Abortion in the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Abortion in North America}}
[[Category:Abortion by country|Saint Kitts and Nevis]] [[Category:Abortion in the Americas|Saint Kitts and Nevis]] [[Category:Abortion in the Caribbean|Saint Kitts and Nevis]] [[Category:Health in Saint Kitts and Nevis]] [[Category:Saint Kitts and Nevis law]]

revision.comment: recategorize
revision.text:
'''Abraham Low''' (1891–1954), was a [[Jewish]]-[[United States|American]] [[Neuropsychiatry|neuropsychiatrist]] noted for his work establishing self-help programs for the mentally ill, and criticism of [[Sigmund Freud|Freudian]] [[psychoanalysis]].<ref name="KEOGH1979">{{cite book | author = Keogh, C.B. | authorlink = Cornelius Keogh | url = http://publishing.yudu.com/Freedom/Actiz/GROWcomesofageaceleb/resources/ | title = GROW Comes of Age: A Celebration and a Vision! | year = 1979 | publisher = GROW Publications | location = [[Sydney, Australia]] | isbn = 978-0-909114-01-5 | oclc = 27588634 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090221091901/http://publishing.yudu.com/Freedom/Actiz/GROWcomesofageaceleb/resources/ | archivedate = 2009-02-21 | df = }}</ref><ref name="SAGARINMENTAL1969">{{cite book |last=Sagarin |first=Edward |authorlink=Edward Sagarin |title=Odd Man In: Societies of Deviants in America |year=1969 |publisher=Quadrangle Books |location=[[Chicago, Illinois]] |isbn=978-0-531-06344-6 |oclc=34435 |pages=210–232 |chapter=Chapter 9. Mental patients: are they their brothers' therapists?}}</ref>
==Early years== Low was born February 28, 1891, in [[Baranów Sandomierski]], [[Congress Poland|Poland]].<ref name="SARNIA2000">{{cite web |url=http://www.sarnia.com/groups/recoveryinc/drlow.htm |title=Biography of Dr. Abraham A. Low |accessdate=2007-10-15 |date=2000-03-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024043303/http://www.sarnia.com/groups/recoveryinc/drlow.htm |archivedate=2007-10-24 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Low attended [[grade school]], [[high school]] and medical school in France from 1910 to 1918. He continued his medical education in [[Austria]], serving in the Medical Corps of the [[Military of Austria|Austrian Army]]. He graduated with a medical degree in 1919, after his military service, from the [[University of Vienna]] Medical School. After serving an [[internship]] in [[Vienna, Austria]] from 1919 to 1920, he immigrated to the United States, obtaining his U.S. citizenship in 1927.
==Career== From 1921 to 1925 he practiced medicine in both [[New York, New York]] and [[Chicago, Illinois]]. In 1925 he was appointed as an instructor of [[neurology]] at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois]] Medical School and became an associate professor of psychiatry.<ref name="SARNIA2000"/> In 1931 Low was appointed Assistant Director and in 1940 became Acting Director of the University's Neuropsychiatric Institute.<ref name="GROSZ1971">{{cite journal |title=Self-help through Recovery, Inc |last=Grosz |first=H. J. |journal=Current Psychiatric Therapies |volume=11 |year=1971 |pages=156–160 |pmid=5113142}}</ref>
From 1931 to 1941 he supervised the Illinois State Hospitals. During this time he conducted demanding seminars with the staff and interviewed the most severe mental patients in the wards. In 1936, Low's ''Studies in Infant Speech and Thought'' was published by the University of Illinois Press.<ref name="SARNIA2000"/><ref name="LOW1936">{{cite book |last=Low |first=Abraham A. |title=Studies in infant speech and thought |publisher=[[University of Illinois]] |location=[[Urbana, Illinois]] |year=1936 |oclc=14752937}}</ref> Some sixty papers are by Low dealing variously with such topics as: [[Histopathology]] of brain and spinal cord, studies on speech disturbances ([[aphasias]]) in brain lesions, clinical testing of psychiatric and neurological conditions, studies in [[shock therapy (psychiatry)|shock treatment]], laboratory investigations of mental diseases; and several articles on [[group psychotherapy]] had been published in medical periodicals.{{Citation needed|date=October 2007}}
==Death and legacy== In 1954 Low died at the [[Mayo Clinic]] in [[Rochester, Minnesota]]. His contributions to the psychiatric and mental health communities are often not well known, but his work has and continues to assist numerous individuals in the area of mental health.<ref name="SARNIA2000"/>
==Recovery International== {{Main|Recovery International}} In 1937, Low founded [[Recovery International|Recovery, Inc.]] He served as its medical director from 1937 to 1954. During this time he presented lectures to relatives of former patients on his work with these patients and the before and after scenarios. In 1941, Recovery Inc. became an independent organization. Low's three volumes of ''The Technique of Self-help in Psychiatric Aftercare'' (including "Lectures to Relatives of Former Patients") were published by Recovery, Inc. in 1943.<ref name="LOW1943">{{cite book |last = Low |first=Abraham A. |title=Lectures to Relatives of Former Patients |year=1967 |publisher=The Christopher Publishing House |location=[[Boston, MA]] |isbn=978-0-8158-0139-9 |oclc=1410817}}</ref><ref name="RECOVERY1943">{{cite book |title=The techniques of self-help in psychiatric after-care |last=Low |first=Abraham A. |author2=Recovery, Inc. |location=[[Chicago, Illinois]] |year=1943 |oclc=42198367}}</ref> Recovery's main text, ''Mental Health Through Will-Training'', was originally published in 1950.<ref name="LOW1950">{{cite book |last=Low |first=Abraham |title=Mental Health Through Will Training |year=1984 |publisher=Willett Pub |isbn=978-0-915005-01-7 |oclc=9878531 |url=https://archive.org/details/mentalhealththro002066mbp |lccn=57012246}}</ref> During the organization's annual meeting in June 2007 it was announced that Recovery, Inc. would thereafter be known as [[Recovery International]].<ref name="REPORTER2007">{{cite journal |journal=Recovery Reporter |title=Annual Meeting |year=2007 |origyear=2nd Quarter |volume=70 |issue=2 |oclc=22518904 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Abraham Low Self-Help Systems]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{worldcat id|id=lccn-n84-181049}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100120111447/http://www.lowselfhelpsystems.org/ Abraham Low Self-Help Systems] providers of Power to Change and [[Recovery International]] * Robin Pape: [https://biapsy.de/index.php/de/9-biographien-a-z/168-low-abraham Biography of Abraham Low] in: [http://biapsy.de/index.php/en/ Biographical Archive of Psychiatry (BIAPSY)], 2015.
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Low, Abraham}} [[Category:American psychiatrists]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:American psychology writers]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:Developmental psychologists]] [[Category:Jewish American scientists]] [[Category:Polish psychologists]] [[Category:Polish psychiatrists]] [[Category:American Reform Jews]] [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1954 deaths]] [[Category:Physicians from Illinois]] [[Category:Polish emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Scientists from Chicago]] [[Category:University of Vienna alumni]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
'''Agricultural expansion''' describes the growth of [[agricultural land]] ([[arable land]], [[pastures]], etc.) in the 21st century as a direct consequence of [[human overpopulation]] with an estimated 10 to 11 billion humans by end of this century and the required [[food security|food]] and [[energy security]]. It is foreseen that most nonagricultural [[terrestrial ecosystem|terrestrial]] and [[aquatic ecosystem]]s of the world will be [[environmental impact|affected adversely]] ([[habitat loss]], [[land degradation]]). The intensified [[food production|food]] and [[biofuel]] production will particularly affect [[tropical]] regions.
Most modern agriculture relies on [[intensive agriculture|intensive]] methods. Further expansion of the predominant farming types that rest on a small number of [[High-yielding variety|highly productive crops]] has led to a significant [[loss of biodiversity]] on a global scale already.<ref name="Grantham Research Institute on climate change and the environment 2018">{{cite web | title=The expansion of modern agriculture and global biodiversity decline: an integrated assessment | website=[[Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment]] | date=2018-02-19 | url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/GranthamInstitute/publication/running-with-the-red-queen-an-integrated-assessment-of-agricultural-land-expansion-and-global-biodiversity-decline/ | access-date=2018-02-19}}</ref> In the light of the already occurring and potential massive ecological effects, the need for [[sustainable agriculture|sustainable]] practices is more urgent than ever.
The [[FAO]] predicts that global [[arable land]] use will continue to grow from a {{convert | 1.58 | e9ha}} in 2014 to {{convert|1.66 |e9ha}} in 2050, with most of this growth projected to result from [[developing countries]]. At the same time, arable land use in [[developed countries]] is likely to continue its decline.<ref name="Our World in Data">{{cite web | title=Yields and Land Use in Agriculture | website=Our World in Data | url=https://ourworldindata.org/yields-and-land-use-in-agriculture | access-date=2018-02-19}}</ref>
A well-known example of already ongoing agricultural expansion is the proliferation of [[palm oil]] production areas or the [[land conversion]]/[[deforestation]] for [[soy bean]] production in [[South America]]. Today's [[land grabbing]] activities are often a consequence of the strive for agricultural land by [[economic growth|growing]] economies.<ref name="Ceddia Bardsley Gomez-y-Paloma Sedlacek pp. 7242–7247">{{cite journal | last=Ceddia | first=M. G. | last2=Bardsley | first2=N. O. | last3=Gomez-y-Paloma | first3=S. | last4=Sedlacek | first4=S. | title=Governance, agricultural intensification, and land sparing in tropical South America | journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | publisher=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume=111 | issue=20 | date=2014-05-05 | issn=0027-8424 | doi=10.1073/pnas.1317967111 | pages=7242–7247}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Industrial agriculture]] *[[Green revolution]] *[[Environmental impact of agriculture]] *[[Meat consumption]] *[[Overexploitation]] *[[Biodiversity loss]] *[[Carbon sink]] *[[Deforestation]] *[[Land sparing]] *[[Species extinction]]s *[[Jevons paradox]] *[[Social and environmental impact of palm oil]]
==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite journal | last=Laurance | first=William F. | last2=Sayer | first2=Jeffrey | last3=Cassman | first3=Kenneth G. | title=Agricultural expansion and its impacts on tropical nature | journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=29 | issue=2 | year=2014 | issn=0169-5347 | doi=10.1016/j.tree.2013.12.001 | pages=107–116 | ref=harv| quote=The human population is projected to reach 11 billion this century, with the greatest increases in tropical developing nations. This growth, in concert with rising per-capita consumption, will require large increases in food and biofuel production. How will these megatrends affect tropical terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems and biodiversity? We foresee (i) major expansion and intensification of tropical agriculture, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa and South America; (ii) continuing rapid loss and alteration of tropical old-growth forests, woodlands, and semi-arid environments; (iii) a pivotal role for new roadways in determining the spatial extent of agriculture; and (iv) intensified conflicts between food production and nature conservation}} * {{cite journal | last=Tilman | first=D. | title=Global environmental impacts of agricultural expansion: The need for sustainable and efficient practices | journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | publisher=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume=96 | issue=11 | date=1999-05-25 | issn=0027-8424 | doi=10.1073/pnas.96.11.5995 | pages=5995–6000 | ref=harv|quote=The recent intensification of agriculture, and the prospects of future intensification, will have major detrimental impacts on the nonagricultural terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems of the world. The doubling of agricultural food production during the past 35 years was associated with a 6.87-fold increase in nitrogen fertilization, a 3.48-fold increase in phosphorus fertilization, a 1.68-fold increase in the amount of irrigated cropland, and a 1.1-fold increase in land in cultivation. Based on a simple linear extension of past trends, the anticipated next doubling of global food production would be associated with approximately 3-fold increases in nitrogen and phosphorus fertilization rates, a doubling of the irrigated land area, and an 18% increase in cropland. | pmc=34218 }} * {{cite web | title=Crop production and natural resource use | website=World Agriculture: Towards 2015/2030 - [[FAO]] | url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/005/y4252e/y4252e06.htm | ref={{sfnref | World Agriculture: Towards 2015/2030}} | access-date=2018-02-19}}
[[Category:Agriculture]]

revision.text:
{{chembox | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = | ImageFile = Aspergillomarasmine A.svg | ImageSize = 250px | ImageFile1 = | ImageSize1 = 200px | IUPACName = (R-(R*,R*))-N-(2-((2-Amino-2-carboxyethyl)amino)-2-carboxyethyl)-L-aspartic acid{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} | OtherNames = | Section1 = {{Chembox Identifiers | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|changed|??}} | CASNo = 3484-65-9 | ChemSpiderID = 170641 | UNNumber = | UNII = K4F9BJQ6EG | PubChem = 197028 | InChI=1S/C10H17N3O8/c11-4(8(16)17)2-12-6(10(20)21)3-13-5(9(18)19)1-7(14)15/h4-6,12-13H,1-3,11H2,(H,14,15)(H,16,17)(H,18,19)(H,20,21)/t4-,5+,6-/m1/s1 | InChIKey=XFTWUNOVBCHBJR-NGJCXOISSA-N | SMILES = C(C(C(=O)O)NCC(C(=O)O)NCC(C(=O)O)N)C(=O)O}} | Section2 = {{Chembox Properties | Formula = C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>17</sub>N<sub>3</sub>O<sub>8</sub> | MolarMass = 307.257 | Appearance = | Density = | MeltingPtC = | BoilingPtC = | Solubility = | SolubleOther = }} }} '''Aspergillomarasmine A''' is an polyamino acid naturally produced by the mold ''[[Aspergillus versicolor]]''. The substance has been reported to inhibit two [[antibiotic resistance]] [[carbapenemase]] proteins in bacteria, [[New Delhi metallo-beta-lactamase 1]] (NDM-1) and [[Verona integron-encoded metallo-beta-lactamase]] ([[VIM-2]]), and make those antibiotic-resistant bacteria susceptible to antibiotics.<ref name="King2014">{{cite journal|last=King|first=Andrew M.|author2=Sarah A. Reid-Yu |author3=Wenliang Wang |author4=Dustin T. King |author5=Gianfranco De Pascale |author6=[[Natalie Strynadka|Natalie C. Strynadka]] |author7=Timothy R. Walsh |author8=Brian K. Coombes |author9=Gerard D. Wright |year=2014|title=Aspergillomarasmine A overcomes metallo-β-lactamase antibiotic resistance|journal=Nature|volume=510|issue=7506|pages=503–506|issn=0028-0836|doi=10.1038/nature13445|pmid=24965651|bibcode=2014Natur.510..503K |pmc=4981499}}</ref> Aspergillomarasmine A is toxic to leaves of [[barley]] and other plants, being termed as "Toxin C" when produced by ''[[Pyrenophora teres]]''.<ref name="Weiergang2002"/>
The molecule is a tetra[[carboxylic acid]] with four -COOH groups. One section of the molecule is the amino acid [[aspartic acid]]. This has two [[alanine]]{{contradict-inline|date=February 2016}}<!-- not true according to diagram (or at best unusual terminology); this implies usual amine/carboxyl linking from alanine that would have its "CH3" sidechain intact, not an "aminomethyl" amino-acid side-chain --> molecules attached. [[Aspergillomarasmine B]] differs in that the last alanine is replaced by [[glycine]].
The crystalline substance was first isolated in 1956, but its name was given until 1965.<ref name="Haenni1965"/>
In addition to ''Aspergillus versicolor'', aspergillomarasmine A is also produced by the ascomycete ''[[Pyrenophora teres]]'' where it acts as a toxin in the barley [[net-spot blotch disease]]. In ''P. teres'', a biosynthetic precursor of aspergillomarasmine A, ''L'',''L''-''N''-(2-amino-2-carboxyethyl)-aspartic acid<!-- need CAS# for searchers or lead for future own article --> has also been isolated and found to contribute to the phytotoxic properties of this microbe.<ref name="Friis">{{cite journal|last1=Friis|first1=P|author2=Olsen C.E. |author3=Møller B.L. |date=15 July 1991|title=Toxin production in ''Pyrenophora teres'', the ascomycete causing the net-spot blotch disease of barley (''Hordeum vulgare'' L.)|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=266|issue=20|pages=13329–13335|pmid=2071605}}</ref> This precursor, aspergillomarasmine A itself, and a [[lactam]] form (anhydroaspergillomarasmine A) are together termed the '''marasmines'''.<ref name="Weiergang2002"/>
<!-- need gallery: precursor, gallery of AspA, anhydroAspA -->
Other producers of aspergillomarasmine A include ''[[Aspergillus flavus]]'',<ref name="Haenni1965"/> ''[[Aspergillus oryzae]]'',<ref name="WagmanCooper1988">{{cite book|last1=Wagman|first1=G.H.|last2=Cooper|first2=R.|title=Natural Products Isolation: Separation Methods for Antimicrobials, Antivirals and Enzyme Inhibitors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A85gz71Tgy8C&pg=PA499|accessdate=27 June 2014|date=1988-12-01|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780080858487|page=499}}</ref> ''[[Colletotrichum gloeosporioides]]'', and ''[[Fusarium oxysporum]]''.<ref name="Weiergang2002">{{cite journal|last=Weiergang|first=I.|author2=H.J. Lyngs Jørgensen |author3=I.M. Møller |author4=P. Friis |author5=V. Smedegaard-Petersen|year=2002|title=Optimization of in vitro growth conditions of ''Pyrenophora teres'' for production of the phytotoxin aspergillomarasmine A|journal=Physiological and Molecular Plant Pathology|volume=60|issue=3|pages=131–140|issn=0885-5765|doi=10.1006/pmpp.2002.0383}}</ref>
In mice the [[LD50]] toxic dose of aspergillomarasmine A is 159.8 mg/kg.<ref name="Matsuura">{{cite journal|last=Matsuura|first=Akihiro|author2=Hiroshi Okumura |author3=Rieko Asakura |author4=Naoki Ashizawa |author5=Mayumi Takahashi |author6=Fujio Kobayashi |author7=Nami Ashikawa |author8= Koshi Arai |title=Pharmacological profiles of aspergillomarasmines as endothelin converting enzyme inhibitors|journal=The Japanese Journal of Pharmacology|volume=63|issue=2|pages=187–193|doi=10.1254/jjp.63.187|pmid=8283829|year=1993}}</ref>
==Properties== Aspergillomarasmine A takes the form of colourless crystals. The chemical is insoluble in common [[organic solvent]]s, but can dissolve in water under either basic or strongly acidic conditions.<ref name="Haenni1965"/>
Anhydroaspergillomarasmine A, a lactam of aspergillomarasmine A, chemically called [1-(2-amino-2carboxyethyl)-6-carboxy-3-carboxymethyl-3-piperazinone],<!-- need stereochemistry --><!-- need CAS# for searchers or lead for future own article --> can also be found in ''Pyrenophora teres''. The relative amount of these two toxins is dependent upon the pH of the growth medium, with lower pH favouring the lactam form.<ref name="Weiergang2002"/> The lactam can be hydrolyzed to aspergillomarasmine A by treating it with [[trifluoroacetic acid]].<ref name="Weiergang2002"/>
Aspergillomarasmine A functions as a [[chelation|chelating]] agent, sequestering [[Ferric|Fe<sup>3+</sup>]] ions.<ref name="Barbier1987">{{cite journal|last=Barbier|first=M.|year=1987|title=Remarks on the biological activity of aspergillomarasmine A Fe<sup>3+</sup> chelate and other iron transporting phytotoxins with reference to their role in the photodegradation of aromatic amino-acids in infected plant leaves|journal=Journal of Phytopathology|volume=120|issue=4|pages=365–368|issn=0931-1785|doi=10.1111/j.1439-0434.1987.tb00500.x}}</ref> It can inhibit [[endothelin converting enzyme]]s even in the live rat, probably by chelating metals required by [[metalloprotease]]s.<ref name="HugginsPelton1996">{{cite book|last1=Huggins|first1=John P.|last2=Pelton|first2=John T.|title=Endothelins in Biology and Medicine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DkHc7toqDX4C&pg=PA121|accessdate=27 June 2014|date=1996-12-23|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9780849369759|page=121}}</ref>
When heated, aspergillomarasmine A [[Chemical decomposition|decomposes]] between 225° and 236 °C. [[Hydrolysis]] produces L-[[aspartic acid]] and racemic{{why|date=February 2016}}<!-- chemical appears to have two equiv of *same*-chirality of this building-block --> [[2,3-diamino-propionic acid]]. [α]<sup>20°</sup><sub>D</sub> at pH 7 is -48°.<ref name="Haenni1965">{{cite journal|last=Haenni|first=A. L.|author2=M. Robert |author3=W. Vetter |author4=L. Roux |author5=M. Barbier |author6=E. Lederer |year=1965|title=Structure chimique des aspergillomarasmines A et B (Chemical structure of aspergellomarasmines A and B)|journal=Helvetica Chimica Acta|volume=48|issue=4|pages=729–750|issn=0018-019X|doi=10.1002/hlca.19650480409| pmid = 14321962|language=fr}}</ref>{{contradict-inline|date=February 2016}}<!-- this surely isn't the *racemic* chemical's alpha-D! Are we talking about the Asp? Or the title compound? -->
With nitrous acid aspergillomarasmine A is [[deamination|deaminated]],{{clarify|date=February 2016}} and [[isoserine]] with aspartic acid is formed.<ref name="Haenni1965"/>
[[Titration]] reveals changes in ionisation at [[Dissociation constant#pK|pK]] 3.5 and 4.5 due to carboxylic acid groups, and pK 9.5 and 10 due to amino groups.<ref name="Haenni1965"/>{{clarify|date=February 2016}}<!-- there are 4 acids and 3 amines, but only 2 of each are titratable? Which? -->
Treatment with [[ninhydrin]] shows a purple colour.<ref name="Haenni1965"/>
== References == {{Reflist|35em}}
[[Category:Antibiotic resistance]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = CanniMed Therapeutics Inc. | logo = CanniMed logo.svg | caption = | type = Subsidiary | traded_as = {{TSX was|CMED}} | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1988}} | founder = Brent Zettl | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Saskatoon, Saskatchewan]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | location = | locations = | area_served = [[Canada]] | key_people = | industry = [[Medical Cannabis]] | products = [[Medical cannabis]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = [[Aurora Cannabis]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{ubl|{{url|http://www.cannimed.ca/}}}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''CanniMed Therapeutics Inc.''' is a Canadian public licensed producer of [[medical cannabis]]. It is primarily focused on [[cannabis oil]]. The company's predecessor, Prairie Plant Systems, was established in 1988 and is located in [[Saskatoon]], Saskatchewan. In 2013 CanniMed became the first cannabis producer to be licensed under [[Health Canada]] regulations that were issued that year. It went public in 2016, and in March 2018 almost all of its stock was acquired by a rival producer, [[Aurora Cannabis]], following a [[hostile takeover]] to which company management finally consented.
==History== The predecessor to CanniMed, Prairie Plant Systems, was established in 1988. PPS began its business by providing fruit trees to orchards.<ref name=DFP2012>{{cite news|last1=Egan|first1=Paul|title=Part 1: Company wants to grow quality medical marijuana in old mine|url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20120422/NEWS15/204220533/Company-wants-grow-quality-medical-marijuana-old-mine|work=Detroit Free Press|date=April 22, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151008151217/http://archive.freep.com/article/20120422/NEWS15/204220533/Company-wants-grow-quality-medical-marijuana-old-mine|archivedate=October 8, 2015}} {{cite news|last1=Egan|first1=Paul|title=Part 2: Underground pot farm could breathe new life into U.P. mining town|url=http://www.freep.com/article/20120423/NEWS15/204230351/Underground-pot-farm-could-breathe-new-life-into-U-P-mining-town|work=Detroit Free Press|date=April 23, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425211500/http://www.freep.com/article/20120423/NEWS15/204230351/Underground-pot-farm-could-breathe-new-life-into-U-P-mining-town|archivedate=April 25, 2012}}</ref> Fruit products include [[Saskatoon berries]], [[haskap]] (blue honeysuckle) and dwarf [[sour cherries]]. In 1990, it entered a joint venture with [[Hudbay Minerals|Hudson Bay Mining]] to establish an underground growth chamber in the Trout Lake mine in [[Flin Flon]], Manitoba.<ref name=":3" />
In 2000, PPS received a contract from Health Canada to grow medical cannabis.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/witsem/vol40|title=The Medicalization of Cannabis.Wellcome Witnesses to Twentieth Century Medicine, vol. 40.|date=2010|publisher=Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine at UCL|isbn=9780854841295|editor1-last=Crowther|editor1-first=S M|location=London|editor2-last=Reynolds|editor2-first=L A|editor3-last=Tansey|editor3-first=E M}}</ref> It used its facility in Flin Flon for this purpose.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/medical-marijuana-operation-halted-in-flin-flon-1.780494|title=Medical marijuana operation halted in Flin Flon|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en}}</ref> From that time until 2013, PPS was the only company given a Health Canada license to grow cannabis, although as of 2012 only 12% of medical cannabis users used PPS, with most of the rest growing their own cannabis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/m/touch/health/story/1.799488|title=CBC News - Marijuana's journey to legal health treatment: the Canadian experience|website=www.cbc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-01-23}}</ref> In 2000 PPS set up a US subsidiary called SubTerra, and in 2003, it acquired the [[White Pine mine]] in Michigan, for use in bio-pharmaceutical research.<ref name=DFP2012/> In 2009, PPR lost its lease to the Flin Flon facility when a deposit of zinc was discovered below it, and so the company built its first above-ground cannabis growing facility.<ref>{{cite web|title=Clean Innovation in Focus: Prairie Plant Systems Inc.|url=http://cetacwest.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Prairie-Plant-Systems-CetacWest-SuccessStory.pdf|publisher=CETAC-WEST|date=June 2017}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/opinion/analysis/high-times-over-for-marijuana-mine-161407325.html|title=High times over for marijuana mine|last=Naylor|first=Jonathon|date=2012-07-05|work=Winnipeg Free Press|access-date=2018-01-23}}</ref>
In 2012, PPS through SubTerra announced its intention to grow medical cannabis in its Michigan mine, based on the 2008 legalization of medical cannabis in Michigan.<ref name=DFP2012/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2012/04/23/michigan-medical-marijuana-mine_n_1445525.html|title=Medical Marijuana Grow-Op|work=Huffington Post|last=Associated Press|date=April 23, 2012}}</ref> In 2014 SubTerra bought an Upper Michigan power company in order to secure energy supply to its research facilities.<ref>{{cite news|title=White Pine Power Plant Sold; Traxys Sale Completed|url=http://www.keweenawreport.com/news/traxys-sale-completed/|work=Keneewa Report|date=August 27, 2014}}</ref>
In 2013, Health Canada changed its medical cannabis regulations, banning in-home production and opening up commercial production to additional companies, and that year PPS and its new subsidiary '''CanniMed Ltd.''' became first producers to be certified under the regulations.<ref name=GandM>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/veteran-medical-marijuana-provider-seizing-canadas-open-market/article14694198/|title=Veteran medical marijuana provider seizing Canada's open market|publisher=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ottawa awards first medical pot licences under new rules to Saskatoon firm|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/health/ottawa-awards-first-medical-pot-licences-under-new-rules-to-saskatoon-firm-1.1466653|publisher=CTV News|first=Jennifer |last=Graham|date=September 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Authorized Licensed Producers under the Marihuana for Medical Purposes Regulations|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/dhp-mps/marihuana/info/list-eng.php|publisher=Health Canada|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref>
In June 2015 CanniMed received [[Health Canada]] approval for clinical trial of cannabis in adults with [[osteoarthritis]] of the knee.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/british-columbia/medical-leaders-call-for-more-research-into-benefits-of-pot/article24993936/|title=More medical research needed to confirm benefits of pot, doctors say|publisher=[[National Post]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/dalhousie-s-medical-marijuana-study-to-evaluate-effect-on-arthritis-1.3126098|title=Dalhousie's medical marijuana study to evaluate effect on arthritis|publisher=[[CBC News]]}}</ref> In January 2016, CanniMed received Health Canada approval to sell edible cannabis oil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/2449723/cannimed-receives-approval-from-health-canada-to-sell-cannabis-oil/|title=CanniMed receives approval from Health Canada to sell cannabis oil|work=Global News|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en}}</ref> On December 29, 2016, it held an IPO on the [[Toronto Stock Exchange]], raising $69 million.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://thestarphoenix.com/business/local-business/cannimed-plans-10-5-million-expansion-at-saskatoon-plant|title=CanniMed plans $10.5 million expansion at Saskatoon plant|date=2017-04-19|work=Saskatoon StarPhoenix|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}}</ref> The new public company was named CanniMed Therapeutics, and had Cannimed Ltd. and Prairie Plant Systems as subsidiaries. In March 2017, it announced a deal to distribute its products with [[PharmaChoice]], a Canadian co-operative pharmacy chain.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://calgaryherald.com/business/local-business/aurora-cannabis-considers-entering-retail-market-amid-uncertainty-it-will-be-allowed|title=Aurora Cannabis considers entering retail market amid uncertainty it will be allowed|date=2017-09-06|work=Calgary Herald|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}}</ref> In April 2017, it announced a $10 million expansion of its facility in Saskatoon.<ref name=":1" />
In November 2017, [[Aurora Cannabis]] started trying to acquire CanniMed, and claimed it had the support of 38% of shareholders.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/cannimed-therapeutics-aurora-cannnabis-takeover-bid-1.4403189|title=CanniMed tells shareholders to wait while it reviews Aurora offer|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en}}</ref> CanniMed management responded by rejecting the offer, and proposing an alternative merger with Newstrike Resources, a recreational cannabis firm, instead.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/aurora-cannabis-cannimed-therapeutics-takeover-bid-1.4417757|title=Aurora takeover bid 'makes no sense,' based on inflated share price: CanniMed|work=CBC News|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en}}</ref> In January, Newstrike shareholders approved the proposed merger,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ca.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idCAKBN1F62YO-OCABS|title=Up Cannabis-parent Newstrike's shareholders approve sale to CanniMed|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=CA|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-CA}}</ref> but CanniMed management started to reconsider Aurora's offer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://business.financialpost.com/news/cannimed-postpones-shareholder-vote-will-hold-talks-with-suitor-aurora-cannabis|title=CanniMed postpones shareholder vote, will hold talks with suitor Aurora Cannabis|website=business.financialpost.com|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref> In January 2018, Cannimed called off its proposed acquisition of Newstrik and agreed to be bought by Aurora for $1.1 billion in stock and cash to create a larger company than the industry leader at the time, [[Canopy Growth Corporation]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Saminather|first1=Nichola|title=Canada's Aurora Cannabis to buy rival to create world's most valuable weed firm|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-cmed-m-a-auroracannabis/canadas-aurora-cannabis-to-buy-rival-to-create-worlds-most-valuable-weed-firm-idUSKBN1FD1T6|work=Reuters|date=January 24, 2018}}</ref> Aurora had put out an offer to buy CanniMed's stock from its holders for cash and Aurora stock; the offer terminated at the end of March and by that time Aurora owned around 96% of CanniMed stock, and had paid out around 69.3 million of its shares and $134 million in cash.<ref name=AP/> Aurora said at that time that it would compel the remaining shareholders to sell their stock and would formally absorb CanniMed at a later date.<ref name=AP>{{cite news|title=Press release: Aurora Cannabis Finalizes CanniMed Acquisition|url=https://www.newcannabisventures.com/aurora-cannabis-finalizes-cannimed-acquisition/|work=Aurora via New Cannabis Ventures|date=March 28, 2018}}</ref> In April 2018 the CEO of CanniMed, Brent Zettl, resigned and Andre Jerome was appointed interim CEO.<ref>{{cite news|title=CanniMed CEO resigns, Aurora Cannabis SVP takes role in interim|url=http://www.canadianbusiness.com/business-news/cannimed-ceo-resigns-aurora-cannabis-svp-takes-role-in-interim/|work=Canadian Business|date=5 April 2018}}</ref> Around the time of acquisition CanniMed's stock price rose dramatically as people anticipated the legalization of [[cannabis in Canada]] in the summer of 2018, raising concerns about a [[Economic bubble|bubble]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Murphy|first1=Mike|title=Getting too high? Canadian marijuana stocks skyrocket, raising bubble fears|url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/getting-too-high-canadian-marijuana-stocks-skyrocket-raising-bubble-fears-2018-04-02|work=MarketWatch|date=April 3, 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.cannimed.ca/ Official CanniMed website] * [http://www.prairieplant.com/ Official Prairie Plant Systems website]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} '''Capital punishment in New Zealand''' first appeared in a codified form when it became a British territory in 1840, and was first employed in 1842.<ref name="TVNZ_History">{{cite web|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/a-history-capital-punishment-in-nz-2423716|title=A history of capital punishment in NZ|date=17 December 2008|publisher=TVNZ|accessdate=10 February 2009}}</ref> It was last used in 1957, abolished for murder in 1961, and abolished altogether, including for treason, in 1989. During the period that it was in effect, 85 people were [[execution (legal)|executed]].
==Method== The method of execution was always by [[hanging]]. At first, there were many possible execution sites all around the country, but later, the only two cities where hangings were carried out were [[Wellington]] (the capital) and [[Auckland]] (now the largest city). Initially, there was no professional hangman employed—the executioner was simply chosen from among any who were deemed qualified. On occasion, convicted criminals were employed as hangmen, often in exchange for reduced sentences or monetary reward. In 1877, the sheriff of [[Blenheim, New Zealand|Blenheim]] recommended that a professional executioner be hired. [[Tom Long (hangman)|Tom Long]], an [[Ireland|Irishman]] who claimed to have been an executioner in [[Australia]], was hired as the first official hangman. He was the only official hangman to be publicly known; others remained anonymous.
==History== The first person to be sentenced to death was a [[Māori people|Māori]] youth named Maketu, who was found guilty of murdering a [[Pākehā|pakeha]] shepherd. However, he died of [[dysentery]] before the sentence could be carried out. The first person to be executed was [[Wiremu Kingi Maketu]], who was found guilty of murdering five people on [[Motuarohia Island]], in the [[Bay of islands|Bay of Islands]]. The people killed were Thomas Bull, employed by Elisabeth Roberton, who was also murdered along with her son aged eight, her daughter of two, and a girl of nearly three named Isabella Brind, the natural daughter of one Captain Brind by a Maori woman, the daughter of Rewa, chief of Ngapuhi in that area. Mrs Roberton's husband, Captain John Roberton, had drowned prior in Paroa Bay, just opposite the island. Thomas Bull had a reputation for strength and brutality. He seemed at all times to have made a set at Maketu and had on several occasions struck, thrown, or otherwise maltreated him. Maketu, was unable to defend himself against such an opponent; nor indeed did it conform with his notions of dignity to do so, he being by virtue of his chiefly rank above combat with one who was a servant and whom he therefore regarded on the same plane as a slave. Maketu, therefore, bided his time for revenge. Maketu then killed Thomas Bull in the night with an axe; he then brutally murdered Mrs Roberton, who was shouting abuse at him and then went to murder the two girls (ransacking the house and then burning Mrs Roberton and the two children within it). The boy ran up Pa Hill, where Maketu chased him and threw him off the {{convert|200|ft|-1|adj=on}} cliff. He was sentenced to death by an [[all-white jury]] (his defence had wanted a half-white, half-Māori jury) in an Auckland court, and executed in March 1842.
All the people executed were men, except [[Minnie Dean]], found guilty of [[infanticide]] in 1895, and all were convicted of murder, except for [[Hamiora Pere]], convicted of [[treason]]. However, before Dean's trial, imprisonment and execution, several other women had been found guilty of [[Infanticide in nineteenth-century New Zealand]], but had had their death sentences commuted to life imprisonment. These were [[Caroline Whitting]] (1872), [[Phoebe Veitch]] (1883) and [[Sarah-Jane and Anna Flannagan]] (1891). The last person to be executed was [[Walter James Bolton]], for poisoning his wife, on 18 February 1957.<ref name="TVNZ_History"/>
==Abolition: 1949–1961== When the [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour Party]] formed its first government following the [[New Zealand general election, 1935|1935 general election]], it commuted all death sentences to [[Life imprisonment in New Zealand|life imprisonment]]. In 1941, the Crimes Amendment Act changed the penalty for murder from death to life imprisonment with [[hard labor|hard labour]]. The only crimes for which the death penalty still applied were [[treason]] and [[piracy]].
The Labour Party lost power to the more conservative [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]], which had pledged to reintroduce capital punishment, in 1949. During that earlier period, support and opposition for capital punishment were clearly delineated on partisan grounds. The National Party supported the restoration and maintenance of the death penalty, while the Labour Party opposed it.<ref>Yska, 1996: 33</ref> During debate over the Capital Punishment Act 1950, Labour expressed concern about the constitutional implications of the concentration of executive power in this context, while National Party Attorney-General Clifton Webb referred to the alleged "deterrent" value of the death penalty as potential threat and punitive severity.<ref>Yska, 1996: 34</ref> However, Webb was relatively sparing in his use of the death penalty, while his successor, Attorney-General Jack Marshall (1955–1958), was a hardliner on that issue and the number and pace of executions accelerated, arousing debate.
During the time that the National Party was in office (1949–1958), 36 people were convicted of murder, and 22 of those were sentenced to death. The final decision on executions rested with [[New Zealand Cabinet|Cabinet]], and only eight of the condemned were executed. The rest were commuted to life imprisonment. Even then, professional opinion was divided. Film censor Gordon Mirams did not regard spectacles of hanging as appropriate content within crime dramas and western films and excised such content and dialogue on the basis of family propriety.<ref>Yska, 1996: 116</ref>
According to Department of Justice historian Pauline Engel, the British Royal Commission on Capital Punishment (1953) may have heavily influenced the rise of abolitionism, as did the controversies that surrounded the executions of Harry Whiteland and [[Edward Thomas Te Whiu|Edward Te Whiu]],<ref>{{DNZB|Young|Sherwood|5T11|Te Whiu, Edward Thomas 1935–1955|9 April 2011}}</ref> which raised questions about post-war trauma, intellectual and developmental disability as factors for leniency.
Social historian Redmer Yska has argued that such concern arose much earlier. When the National Party restored capital punishment in 1950, it became an administrative ordeal for civil servants involved, particularly those within correctional facilities like Mount Eden Prison in Auckland, law enforcement and the judiciary.<ref>Yska, 1996: 154</ref> Corrections staff needed to maintain suicide watch for the convicted felon, conduct regular health checks and provide pastoral care for the condemned individual's relatives, as well as insure prison security during executions.<ref name="Yska, 1996: 164">Yska, 1996: 164</ref>
Official requirements mandated the presence of a magistrate, doctor and sheriffs.<ref name="Yska, 1996: 165">Yska, 1996: 165</ref> During the late fifties, Attorney-General Jack Marshall accelerated the pace of executions and post-traumatic stress disorder, alcoholism and duodenal haemorrhaging developed amongst two of the three staff obliged to participate during execution procedures.<ref name="Yska, 1996: 165"/> In cases of political import, prudent reprieves and commuted penalties did occur, as happened when three Niue Islanders were sentenced to death after killing a manifestly brutal and oppressive Resident Commissioner. On that occasion, the Public Questions Committee of the Presbyterian Church of New Zealand became involved in strenuously lobbying against the verdict.<ref name="Yska, 1996: 165"/>
Class differences were also seen to affect the verdict. Dr. Senga Wintringham was convicted of manslaughter, rather than murder, in February 1955, after shooting and killing Dr Bill Saunders. Wintringham claimed that she had only meant to intimidate him, rather than kill him. ''The Peoples Voice'', newspaper of the Communist Party of New Zealand, criticised the perceived "double standard" in this context, as the courts had just convicted and sentenced nineteen-year-old British migrant and itinerant labourer Frederick Foster to death, despite questions about mental illness and intellectual impairment in his context, as well as appeals from his mother.<ref>Yska, 1996: 166</ref> Foster had shot and killed Sharon Skeffington, his former girlfriend. Although Foster was sentenced to death and executed, defence counsel Dr Martyn Finlay succeeded in raising questions about the limited intellectual capabilities and mental health of the condemned person in this context.<ref>Yska, 1996: 161</ref> Similar questions would arise in the trial, conviction and execution of Albert Webb. The ''New Zealand Listener'' editorialised against the death penalty in July 1955, and received supportive feedback from its letters page correspondents.<ref>Yska, 1996: 187</ref>
[[Edward Thomas Te Whiu|Eddie Te Whiu]] was hanged in August 1955, after he had killed an elderly widow in [[Whangarei|Ngararatunua]], near [[Kamo, New Zealand|Kamo]], when an attempted burglary went wrong.<ref name="DNZB Te Whiu">{{DNZB|title=Edward Thomas Te Whiu|first= Sherwood|last= Young|id=5t11|accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref> Abolitionist sentiment grew again, as, with the Foster and Black cases, there was perceptible anxiety about the failure of "deterrence" value in the context of violent homicides, and whether Te Whiu should have been convicted of manslaughter instead, due to his dysfunctional family origins and limited intellectual capabilities.<ref>Yska, 1996: 188</ref> As a result, a National Committee for Abolition of the Death Penalty was formed in November 1956, with branches in Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch and Dunedin.
Engel and Maureen Garing have drawn attention to the involvement of Protestant Christian opposition to capital punishment. In 1941 and 1951, the Christian Social Justice League, Christchurch Anglican Diocesan Synod and Methodist Public Questions Committee supported abolition, as did individual Catholics, although their hierarchy remained neutral in this debate. The New Zealand Theosophical Society also opposed capital punishment, and the Churches of Christ and Baptist Union declared its opposition in the late fifties. As religious opposition grew, it provided opponents of capital punishment with an organisational base that was used to good effect. Redmer Yska notes that clergy often refused to participate in legitimising executions through their presence, of whatever denomination.<ref name="Yska, 1996: 164"/>
As a consequence of controversy over the perceived escalation in use of capital punishment, abolitionist petitions started to circulate as well. In 1956, a proposal for a referendum on capital punishment was put forward by the [[Minister of Justice (New Zealand)|Minister of Justice]], [[Jack Marshall]]. This referendum was to be voted on during the [[New Zealand general election, 1957|1957 general election]], but the proposal was defeated.
Meanwhile, [[Walter James Bolton]] (1888–1957) was executed at [[Mount Eden Prison]] in [[Auckland]] in February 1957, after he had allegedly poisoned his wife with arsenic. Given that the National Party lost that election, there were to be no further executions within New Zealand. However, while the election saw a short-lived Labour government elected, capital punishment was not debated in Parliament again before the National party regained power after the [[New Zealand general election, 1960|1960 election]].
In 1961, the National Party reaffirmed its support for the death penalty, although restricted its use to premeditated murders, and those committed during another crime or during an escape from custody. The issue of capital punishment generated intensive debate within the National Party—the Minister of Justice in the [[Second National Government of New Zealand|Second National Government]], who was responsible for introducing the Crimes Bill 1961, [[Ralph Hanan]], strongly opposed the death penalty, while Jack Marshall, the [[Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand|Deputy Prime Minister]], had condoned its use while serving as Minister of Justice and Attorney General, as noted above.
==Abolition and its aftermath: 1961 onwards==
Aware of growing public opposition to capital punishment, the National Party allowed its MPs to exercise a [[conscience vote]] in Parliament, and ten National MPs subsequently voted in favour of abolition. The result was a majority of 11 against capital punishment, 41-30. The ten National MPs were Rev. [[Ernest Aderman]], [[Gordon Grieve]], [[Ralph Hanan]], [[Duncan MacIntyre (New Zealand politician)|Duncan MacIntyre]], [[Robert Muldoon]], [[Herbert Pickering]], [[Logan Sloane]], [[Brian Talboys]], Mrs [[Esme Tombleson]] and [[Bert Walker (politician)|Bert Walker]]. The death penalty was therefore abolished for murder, being retained only for treason and other similar acts in theory. In principle, this meant that de facto abolition had occurred from that point onward.<ref name="TVNZ_History"/>
These last theoretical vestiges of capital punishment were abolished under the Palmer Labour cabinet in November 1989 with the passage of the ''Abolition of the Death Penalty Act 1989'', and there were no further executions during the interim period.<ref name="TVNZ_History"/> Passage of the ''Abolition of the Death Penalty Act'' ended all capital punishment in New Zealand. The [[Cook Islands]], which based its statutes on New Zealand law, formally retained the death penalty for treason until it was abolished in 2007. The death penalty was never used in the Cook Islands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/view_release.php?release_id%3D1001 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=22 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206221202/http://www.cook-islands.gov.ck/view_release.php?release_id=1001 |archivedate=6 February 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Occasional calls to reinstate capital punishment still occur, but no major political party has made capital punishment an element of any of their election manifestos since the 1989 Abolition act.
A 2004 [[1 News]] Colmar Brunton poll found 28% were in favour of bringing back the death penalty, 67% did not want to bring the death penalty back, and 5% were undecided. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3578428 |title=Poll shows 28pc want death penalty back – National – NZ Herald News |website=Nzherald.co.nz |date=15 July 2004 |accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref> In a 2013 Curia poll for [[Three (New Zealand)|TV3]]’s ''The Nation'', 38% of New Zealanders were in favour of the death penalty—a nominal increase from the 28% in 2004—while 55% were opposed it, and 7% were undecided. Also in the poll, 35% of Labour voters favoured the death penalty and National voters' support polled at 44%. Least likely to be in favour were Green Party voters at 19%, but the strongest support came from New Zealand First voters at 84%. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nbr.co.nz/article/sizeable-support-reintroduction-death-penalty-ck-144558 |title=Sizeable support for reintroduction of death penalty | The National Business Review |website=Nbr.co.nz |date=18 August 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.curia.co.nz/2013/08/death-penalty-poll/ |title=Death Penalty poll – Curia Market Research Ltd |website=Curia.co.nz |date=24 August 2013 |accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of people executed in New Zealand]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== *Creswell, J.C.M. (1998) ''Murder in paradise: The strange adventures of the Roberton brothers'' Whangarei: J.M. Glover {{ISBN|1-876135-00-X}} *Engel, Pauline (1977): ''The Abolition of Capital Punishment in New Zealand'': Wellington: Department of Justice. *Gee, David (1975). ''The devil's own brigade: A History of Lyttelton Gaol: ''Wellington: Millwood Press. *Garing, Maureen (1994): "Lex talionis and the Christian Churches: The Question of Capital Punishment in New Zealand" (p. 112–122) in J.Veitch (ed) ''To Strive and Not to Yield: Essays in Honour of Colin Brown'': Wellington: Victoria University Department of Religious Studies: {{ISBN|0-475-11013-7}} *Harcourt, Melville (1942). ''A Parson In Prison'': Auckland: Whitcombs and Tombs. *Howard League for Penal Reform (1949) ''Capital Punishment: An Inquiry:'' Wellington: Howard League for Penal Reform. *Newbold, Greg (1990). "Capital Punishment in New Zealand: An Experiment that Failed" ''Deviant Behaviour'': 11:2 (April 1990): 154–177. *Ross, Cuthbert (1993) ''Issues in the Death Penalty Debate in New Zealand: 1935–1992'' LLB (Hons) Dissertation: University of Auckland Faculty of Law *Treadwell, C A L (1936). ''Notable New Zealand Trials'': New Plymouth: T.Avery. *Young, Sherwood (1998) ''Guilty on the Gallows: Famous Capital Crimes of New Zealand'': Wellington: Grantham House: {{ISBN|1-86934-068-X}} *Yska, Redmer (1996) ''All Shook Up'': Auckland: Penguin: 1996: {{ISBN|0-14-016999-7}} *''Meccano Set'', a program by [[Radio New Zealand]] produced by Matthew Leonard and Paul Diamond
==External links== *[http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/culture/the-death-penalty ''Capital Punishment in New Zealand'' at NZHistory.net] *[http://www.teara.govt.nz/1966/C/CapitalPunishment/CapitalPunishment/en Capital Punishment in 1966 ''Encyclopaedia of New Zealand''] *''[http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1989/0119/latest/DLM193572.html Abolition of the Death Penalty Act 1989]'' *[http://www.dnzb.govt.nz/dnzb/default.asp ''Dictionary of New Zealand Biography'' (articles on Maketu, Dean, Marshall, and Hanan)] *''[http://www.howardleague.co.nz/?page_id=24 The Howard League]'' {{capital punishment}}
