{{redirect|Trumpcare|unsuccessful attempts by Congress to repeal the ACA|American Health Care Act of 2017}} {{Infobox U.S. Presidential Document | executiveorder = 13813 | longtitle = ''Executive Order Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition'' | name = Executive Order 13813<ref>{{cite web|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2017-22677.pdf|title=EXECUTIVE ORDER 13813|work=[[Amazon S3]]|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|location=United States|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary|Office of the Press Secretary]]|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/10/12/presidential-executive-order-promoting-healthcare-choice-and-competition|title=Presidential Executive Order Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition Across the United States|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]|publisher=[[White House]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/10/17/2017-22677/promoting-healthcare-choice-and-competition-across-the-united-states|title=Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition Across the United States|work=[[Federal Register]]|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-10-17/pdf/2017-22677.pdf|archivedate=October 17, 2017|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> | othershorttitles = | shorttitle = | depiction = | depictioncaption = | depictionalt = | documentimage = | documentcaption = | signeddate = {{Start date|2017|10|12}} | signedpresident = Donald Trump | summary = {{bulleted list|Allows insurance companies to sell low-cost short-term plans with lesser coverage;|Enables small business to collectively purchase association health plans;|Expands health savings accounts}} | type = Executive order | documentnumber = 2017-22677 | publicationdate = {{Start date|2017|10|17}} | documentcitation = 82-48385 }} The '''Executive Order Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition''', also known as the '''Trumpcare Executive Order''', or '''Trumpcare''',<ref name="Klein">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/daily-on-healthcare-trumpcare-is-coming-to-an-association-health-plan-near-you/article/2176901|title=Daily on Healthcare: Trumpcare is coming to an association health plan near you|first1=Philip|last1=Klein|first2=Robert|last2=King|first3=Kimberly|last3=Leonard|magazine=[[The Washington Examiner]]|publisher=Clarity Media Group|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=October 9, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171009210827/http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/daily-on-healthcare-trumpcare-is-coming-to-an-association-health-plan-near-you/article/2176901|archivedate=October 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Gleckman">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/howardgleckman/2017/10/13/middle-income-50-somethings-will-be-big-losers-in-trumpcare/#49166ba37f79|title=Middle Income 50-Somethings Will Be Big Losers In Trumpcare|first=Howard|last=Gleckman|magazine=[[Forbes]]|publisher=Forbes, Inc.|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 13, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> is an [[Executive order (United States)|Executive Order]] signed by President [[Donald Trump]] on October 12, 2017, which directs federal agencies to modify how the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] of the Obama Administration is implemented. The order included a directive to federal agencies to end rules forbidding employers from using [[Health Reimbursement Account|health reimbursement arrangements]] (HRAs) to pay individual insurance premiums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/10/12/news/economy/trump-health-care-executive-order/|title=What's in Trump's health care executive order?|first=Tami|last=Luhby|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|location=[[Atlanta]]|date=October 13, 2017|accessdate=October 14, 2017}}</ref>
In a separate announcement made shortly after the order was signed, Trump announced that he would end subsidies to health insurance companies that sell to low-income consumers through the state [[health insurance marketplace]]s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/12/politics/obamacare-subsidies/index.html|title=Trump will end health care cost-sharing subsidies|first=Kevin|last=Liptak|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|location=[[Atlanta]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/12/us/politics/trump-obamacare-executive-order-health-insurance.html|title=Trump to Scrap Critical Health Care Subsidies, Hitting Obamacare Again|publisher=New York Times|author=Robert Pear, Maggie Haberman and Reed Abelson|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 14, 2017}}</ref>
Some sources have described the effect of these executive actions as replacing Obamacare with a new healthcare regime; several days after signing the order, Donald Trump himself stated in a press conference that reporters should no longer refer to "Obamacare" because "it's gone, there is no such thing as Obamacare anymore".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2017/10/16/trump-no-such-thing-as-obamacare-anymore-sot-ip.cnn|title=Trump: No such thing as Obamacare anymore|author=<!--- Not stated --->|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|location=[[Atlanta]]|date=October 16, 2017|accessdate=October 18, 2017}}</ref>
==History== ===Legislative efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act=== {{See also|Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act#Implementation history|Efforts to repeal the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act}} The first executive order signed by U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], executed just hours after he was sworn into office on January 20, 2017, was [[Executive Order 13765]], titled ''Executive Order Minimizing the Economic Burden of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act Pending Repeal''. The order set out interim procedures in anticipation of repeal of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (popularly known as the ACA, or Obamacare).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-signs-first-executive-order-targeting-obamacare-003207661.html?soc_src=mail&soc_trk=ma|title=Trump signs first executive order, targeting Obamacare with few specifics|last=Knox|first=Olivier|date=January 20, 2017|work=[[Yahoo! News]]|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|language=en-US|location=[[Sunnyvale, California]]|access-date=October 13, 2017}}</ref> The order came on Trump's campaign pledges to repeal the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/20/us/politics/trump-executive-order-obamacare.html|title=Trump Issues Executive Order Scaling Back Parts of Obamacare|last=Davis|first=Julie Hirschfeld|date=January 20, 2017|last2=Pear|first2=Robert|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|access-date=January 23, 2017}}</ref> which Trump stated would take a long time, with a replacement possibly not being ready until 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/health-care-news/articles/2017-02-06/donald-trump-obamacare-replacement-could-take-a-year|title=Trump Appears to Push Back Obamacare Replacement|first=Kimberly|last=Leonard|work=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|publisher=U.S. News & World Report, L.P.|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=February 6, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref>
On May 4, 2017, the [[United States House of Representatives]] voted to pass the [[American Health Care Act of 2017]] (ACHA) by a narrow margin of 217–213, sending the bill to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] for deliberation.<ref name="NYT-20170504a">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/us/politics/health-care-bill-vote.html|title=House Passes Measure to Repeal and Replace the Affordable Care Act|first1=Thomas|last1=Kaplan|first2=Robert|last2=Pear|date=May 4, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504193733/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/us/politics/health-care-bill-vote.html|archivedate=May 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="NYT-20170504b">{{cite news|last=Sanger-Katz|first=Margot|authorlink=Margot Sanger-Katz|title=Who Wins and Who Loses in the Latest G.O.P. Health Care Bill|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/upshot/who-wins-and-who-loses-in-the-latest-gop-health-care-bill.html |date=May 4, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20170504211701/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/04/upshot/who-wins-and-who-loses-in-the-latest-gop-health-care-bill.html?_r=0|archivedate=May 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="house-count">{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll256.xml|title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 256|last1=[[Clerk of the United States House of Representatives]]|date=May 4, 2017|work=[[United States House of Representatives]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504235141/http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2017/roll256.xml|archive-date=October 12, 2017|dead-url=no|accessdate=|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="CNN-passage">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/05/04/politics/health-care-vote/|title=House Republicans pass bill to repeal and replace Obamacare|first=MJ|last=Lee|work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|location=[[Atlanta]]|date=May 4, 2017|accessdate=May 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505115246/http://edition.cnn.com/2017/05/04/politics/health-care-vote/|archivedate=May 5, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="fox-bill">{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/05/04/republican-health-care-bill-whats-in-it.html|title=Republican health care bill: What's in it?|author=[[Associated Press]]|work=[[Fox News]]|publisher=[[Fox Entertainment Group]]|location=[[New York City]]|accessdate=October 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504141458/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/05/04/republican-health-care-bill-whats-in-it.html|archivedate=May 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It would repeal the parts of the Affordable Care Act within the scope of the federal budget, including provisions contained within the Internal Revenue Code such as the "[[Individual Mandate|individual mandates]]" (in {{USIRC|205}}), [[Employer mandate|employer mandates]] (in {{USIRC|206}}) and various taxes ({{USIRC|201}} et. seq.), and also modifications to the federal Medicaid program (in Sections 111-116 and 121).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1628/all-info#summary|title=All Bill Information (Except Text) for H.R.1628 – American Health Care Act of 2017|last1=[[Clerk of the United States House of Representatives]]|work=[[United States House of Representatives]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=May 4, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170419234437/https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/house-bill/1628/all-info#summary|archivedate=April 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The nonpartisan [[Congressional Budget Office]] projected that the AHCA would increase the number of uninsured people by 23 million over 10 years, but would decrease the federal budget deficit by $119 billion over the same period (about 1%), mainly by cutting [[Medicaid]] coverage for lower income Americans. Both the House AHCA bill and Senate BCRA bill would cut taxes largely for wealthy Americans. Insurance premiums were projected to decrease for younger, healthier, and wealthier people, while older and poorer people would likely see their premiums increase.<ref name="npr-cbo">{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529902300/cbo-republicans-ahca-would-leave-23-million-more-uninsured|title=GOP Health Plan Would Leave 23 Million More Uninsured, Budget Office Says|first=Danielle|last=Kurtzleben|work=[[NPR]]|publisher=National Public Radio, Inc.|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=May 24, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621121045/http://www.npr.org/2017/05/24/529902300/cbo-republicans-ahca-would-leave-23-million-more-uninsured|archivedate=June 21, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Senate [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] initially approached the AHCA with an unprecedented level of secrecy; a group of 13 Republican Senators drafted the Senate's substitute version in private, raising bipartisan concerns about a lack of transparency<ref name="nyt-secrecy">{{cite news|title=Secrecy Surrounding Senate Health Bill Raises Alarms in Both Parties|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/15/us/politics/secrecy-surrounding-senate-health-bill-raises-alarms-in-both-parties.html|first1=Thomas|last1=Kaplan|first2=Robert|last2=Pear|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=June 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170618182849/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/15/us/politics/secrecy-surrounding-senate-health-bill-raises-alarms-in-both-parties.html|archivedate=June 18, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="wapo-remarkable">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/06/13/the-remarkable-steps-republicans-are-taking-to-obscure-whats-in-their-health-care-bill/|title=The remarkable steps Republicans are taking to obscure what’s in their health-care bill|first=Philip|last=Bump|work=[[The Washington Post]]|publisher=[[Jeff Bezos|Nash Holdings LLC]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=June 13, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620082523/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/politics/wp/2017/06/13/the-remarkable-steps-republicans-are-taking-to-obscure-whats-in-their-health-care-bill/|archivedate=June 20, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="shrouded">{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/senate-s-health-care-bill-remains-shrouded-secrecy-n772456|title=The Senate’s Health Care Bill Remains Shrouded in Secrecy|first1=Benjy|last1=Sarlin|first2=Leigh Ann|last2=Caldwell|work=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBC]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=June 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170619162148/http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/senate-s-health-care-bill-remains-shrouded-secrecy-n772456|archivedate=June 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and about the all-male composition of the committee.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Mehreen|last=Kasana|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/the-13-senators-working-on-the-health-care-bill-are-all-men-56291|title="The 13 Senators Working on the Health Care Bill Are All Men"|work=[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]|publisher=Bustle Digital Group|location=[[New York City]]|date=May 7, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Robert|last=Pear|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/08/us/politics/women-health-care-senate.html|title=13 Men, and No Women, Are Writing New G.O.P. Health Bill in Senate|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=May 8, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Michael A.|last=Cohen|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/2017/06/07/why-are-men-behind-closed-doors-writing-health-care-bill/cIqCDEcFo29uxirxbouPbI/story.html|title=“Why are 13 men — behind closed doors — writing the health care bill?”|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners, LLC|location=[[Boston]]|date=June 7, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> On June 22, 2017, Republicans released the first discussion draft for an amendment to the bill.<ref name="BCRA_ERN17282">{{cite web|url=https://www.budget.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/SENATEHEALTHCARE.pdf|title=H.R. 1628, Better Care Reconciliation Act of 2017, discussion draft ERN17282|first=Diane|last=Black|authorlink=Diane Black|work=[[United States Senate Committee on the Budget|Senate Budget Committee]]|publisher=[[United States Senate]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=June 22, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> On July 25, 2017, although no amendment proposal had yet garnered majority support, Senate Republicans voted to advance the bill to the floor and begin formal consideration of amendments.
On July 28, 2017, the bill was returned to [[United States Senate#Calendars|the calendar]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/crec/2017/07/27/CREC-2017-07-27-pt1-PgS4415-2.pdf||title=Congressional Record p. S4415|work=[[United States Senate]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=July 27, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> after the Senate rejected several amendments, including {{USBill|115|S.Amdt.|667}}, the "Skinny Repeal" package offered by Sen. [[Mitch McConnell]], which failed on a 49–51 vote. Sens. [[John McCain]], [[Susan Collins]], and [[Lisa Murkowski]] were the only Republicans to vote against the measure.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=1&vote=00179|title=On the Amendment S.Amdt. 667|first=Diane|last=Black|authorlink=Diane Black|date=July 28, 2017|work=[[United States Senate]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|access-date=October 13, 2017}}</ref> On September 13, 2017, Senators [[Lindsey Graham|Graham]], [[Bill Cassidy|Cassidy]], [[Dean Heller|Heller]], and [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Johnson]] released a draft amendment to the bill<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.lgraham.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?a=Files.Serve&File_id=06822F49-B801-4D9F-95F5-D7B5406E9AA9|title=Amendment in the nature of a substitute to H.R. 1628, discussion draft LYN17709|first=Lindsey|last=Graham|authorlink=Lindsey Graham|work=[[United States Senate]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=September 13, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> that "repeals the structure and architecture of Obamacare and replaces it with a block grant given annually to states".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lgraham.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=DC1FC472-3D15-4948-BB29-548F13ADA9C0|title=Press Release: Graham-Cassidy-Heller-Johnson Background and Endorsements|first=Lindsey|last=Graham|authorlink=Lindsey Graham|work=[[United States Senate]]|publisher=[[United States Congress]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=September 13, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref> However, it was not voted upon due to lack of support. The deadline for Congressional Republicans to end the ACA as part of the [[Reconciliation (United States Congress)|Congressional budget reconciliation process]] (which would enable Senate Republicans to pass new legislation with 51 votes, rather than 60) then expired on September 30, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/deadline-for-fast-track-obamacare-repeal-bill-expires-sept-30/article/2633213|title=Deadline for fast track Obamacare repeal bill expires Sept. 30|first=Robert|last=King|publisher=''[[Washington Examiner]]''|date=September 1, 2017}}</ref>
===Execution of the Executive Order=== Following the failure of Congress to repeal the ACA through legislation, Trump issued the new order. Both supporters and critics asserted that the provisions of the order were intended to redefine the American health care market and effectively replace Obamacare with a new health care regime.<ref name="Klein"/><ref name="Schallhorn">{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/10/12/trump-clears-way-for-obamacare-alternatives-in-new-executive-order-goes-around-stalled-congress.html|title=Trump clears way for ObamaCare 'alternatives' in new executive order, goes around stalled Congress|first1=Kaitlyn|last1=Schallhorn|first2=Serafin|last2=Gomez|work=[[Fox News]]|publisher=[[Fox Entertainment Group]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017}}</ref>{{dubious|"Replacing" Obamacare?|date=October 2017}} Trump briefly forgot to sign the order before leaving the signing ceremony, but was ushered back to the table by Vice President [[Mike Pence]] to complete this step.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/donald-trump-forget-sign-executive-order-healthcare-obamacare-mike-pence-a7997661.html|title=Donald Trump almost forgets to sign executive order before reminder from Mike Pence|first=Alexandra|last=Wilts|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|location=[[London]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 12, 2017}}</ref> Senator [[Rand Paul]], who attended the signing, described the order as "the biggest free market reform of health care in a generation".<ref name="Schallhorn"/>
==Provisions== The order reverses a number of aspects of Obamacare upon which that regime had relied.
Section 1, title "Policy", lays out the policies supporting the provisions of the order, noting that the order directs that the government "facilitate the purchase of insurance across State lines" and prioritizes "[[America's Health Insurance Plans|association health plans]] (AHPs), [[Short-term health insurance|short-term, limited-duration insurance]] (STLDI), and [[Health Reimbursement Account|health reimbursement arrangements]] (HRAs)". Whereas Obamacare had prohibited insurance companies from selling low-cost short term health insurance plans "that can circumvent some of the mandates created under Obamacare",<ref name="Klein"/> such as requiring coverage for persons with preexisting conditions, and requiring coverage for various medical services. The order reversed this prohibition, and also directs the Departments of Health and Human Services, Labor, and Treasury to ease access to "association health plans", which also need not provide the coverage that had been mandated by Obamacare, and expands health savings accounts.<ref name="Klein"/>
Section 2, titled "Expanded Access to Association Health Plans", directs the Secretary of Labor to take steps to "expand access to health coverage by allowing more employers to form AHPs".
Section 3, titled "Expanded Availability of Short-Term, Limited‑Duration Insurance", directs the Secretaries of the Treasury, Labor, and Health and Human Services to take steps to "expand the availability of STLDI".
Section 4, titled "Expanded Availability and Permitted Use of Health Reimbursement Arrangements", directs the Secretaries of the Treasury, Labor, and Health and Human Services to take steps to "increase the usability of HRAs, to expand employers' ability to offer HRAs to their employees, and to allow HRAs to be used in conjunction with nongroup coverage".
==Impact== {{Main|Cost sharing reductions subsidy}} A separate decision on the same day commonly associated with the executive order resulted in no longer paying the cost sharing reduction (CSR) subsidies, which are payments to insurers to keep premiums down for low-income persons. The [[Congressional Budget Office]] reported in August 2017 that not making the CSR payments could increase health insurance premiums on the ACA exchanges by as much as 20% and add nearly $200 billion to the budget deficit over a decade. The deficit increase is because the premium tax credit subsidy (the largest Affordable Care Act subsidy) increases to offset increases in health insurance premium amounts, far outweighing savings from not paying the smaller CSR subsidy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cbo.gov/publication/53009|title=The Effects of Terminating Payments for Cost-Sharing Reduction|work=[[Congressional Budget Office]]|publisher=[[Federal Government of the United States|United States Government]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=August 15, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.cbo.gov/system/files/115th-congress-2017-2018/reports/53009-costsharingreductions.pdf|archivedate=October 17, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Critical response=== Critics described the Executive Order as another part of an ongoing strategy to sabotage the ACA by enabling insurance companies to circumvent ACA mandates and sell insurance that does not cover mandated conditions, and excludes individuals with [[pre-existing condition]]s. Other elements alleged to be part of the sabotage strategy include denying funding not mandated by law for cost sharing reduction (CSR) subsidies, significantly reducing funding for enrollment advertising and support efforts, asserting that the ACA exchanges are in a "death spiral" (contrary to CBO conclusions), and conducting negative advertising campaigns, among other measures.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/10/12/16070724/trump-cost-sharing-reductions-pulled|title=Trump will pull Obamacare subsidies in another attack on health law|first=Dylan|last=Scott|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|location=United States|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/12/opinion/editorials/congress-cant-let-mr-trump-undo-obamacare-on-his-own.html?_r=0|author=Editorial Board|title=Congress Shouldn't Let Mr. Trump Kill Obamacare on His Own|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref>
For example, President Trump tweeted on October 13, 2017 that: "The Democrats ObamaCare is imploding. Massive subsidy payments to their pet insurance companies has stopped. Dems should call me to fix!". Journalist [[Ezra Klein]] wrote that: "Trump has long held the view that if he can inflict sufficient damage to the Affordable Care Act, Democrats will have no choice but to cut a deal — on Trump’s terms — to save it".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2017/10/16/16480438/obamacare-trump-csrs|title=On Obamacare, Donald Trump is sabotaging himself|first=Ezra|last=Klein|authorlink=Ezra Klein|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|location=United States|date=October 16, 2017|accessdate=October 16, 2017}}</ref>
Journalist [[Sarah Kliff]] wrote that: "Trump announced last week he would stop making [CSR] payments. But let's be clear: That decision will cause the federal government to spend billions more subsidizing insurance companies, not less." That is because the savings from reducing CSR payments is less than increases in the insurance premium tax credits, which rise along with sizable (20%+) premium increases for 2018 caused by Trump's threats to the CSR payments during 2017. Kliff used the CBO estimate of $194 billion in higher budget deficits from stopping CSR payments as an estimate of the net impact over a decade.<ref>[https://www.vox.com/health-care/2017/10/18/16499806/trump-insurance-bailouts-completely-incoherent Vox-Sarah Kliff-Trump's stance on insurance "bailouts" is completely incoherent-October 18, 2017]</ref>
Journalist [[David Leonhardt]] wrote on October 15, 2017: "Last week, the administration took several steps to deprive people of health insurance. In doing so, it has both a short-term goal (have the federal government do less to help vulnerable citizens) and a long-term goal (sabotage Obamacare, so that Congress can more easily repeal the law)". He continued: "When [the executive order] takes full effect, it will most likely allow a variety of cheap insurance plans that don’t cover many treatments. These plans will siphon healthy families from the normal markets, raising prices on the sick. It will work nicely for healthy families, until it doesn’t. If they get sick and want insurance that pays for their treatments, they will be out of luck".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/15/opinion/columnists/how-to-fight-the-new-trumpcare.html|title=How to Fight the New Trumpcare|first=David|last=Leonhardt|authorlink=David Leonhardt|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 15, 2017|accessdate=October 15, 2017}}</ref>
According to <i>[[The Economist]]</i>, Trump’s plans "are likely to end up inflicting the most pain on self-employed, middle- to upper-income folk—in other words, on a Republican constituency".<ref name="Economist" >{{cite magazine|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/democracyinamerica/2017/10/poor-pain-management|author=H.C.|title=Donald Trump's health-care orders will hurt middle-class, self-employed Americans|magazine=[[The Economist]]|publisher=[[The Economist Group]]|location=[[City of Westminster|Westminster]], [[London]]|issn=0013-0613|date=October 13, 2017|accessdate=October 13, 2017}}</ref>
====Murray—Alexander Individual Market Stabilization Bill====
{{Main|Murray—Alexander Individual Market Stabilization Bill}}
Senator [[Lamar Alexander]] and Senator [[Patty Murray]] reached a compromise to amend the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] to fund cost cost-sharing reductions.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/us/politics/alexander-murray-deal-obamacare-subsidies.html?_r=0|title=2 Senators Strike Deal on Health Subsidies That Trump Cut Off|first1=Thomas|last1=Kaplan|first2=Robert|last2=Pear|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 17, 2017|access-date=October 18, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> President Trump had stopped paying the cost sharing subsidies and the [[Congressional Budget Office]] estimated his action would cost $200 billion, cause insurance sold on the exchange to cost 20% more and cause one million people to lose insurance.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vox.com/2017/8/15/16153094/voxcare-cbo-trump-obamacare-sabotage-premiums|title=CBO says Trump's Obamacare sabotage would cost $194 billion, drive up premiums 20%|first=Sarah|last=Kliff|work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|location=United States|date=August 15, 2017|access-date=October 17, 2017}}</ref> The plan will also provide more flexibility for state waivers, allow a new "Copper Plan" or catastrophic coverage for all, allow interstate insurance compacts, and redirect consumer fees to states for outreach.
Although Trump initially expressed support for the compromise, he later reversed course by [[Twitter|tweeting]] a dismissive tweet about it.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/18/us/politics/trump-obamacare-subsidies-tweet-opposition.html|title=Trump Pulls Back From Senate Deal to Fund Health Subsidies|first1=Thomas|last1=Kaplan|first2=Tobert|last2=Pear|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|location=[[New York City]]|date=October 18, 2017|accessdate=October 18, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Executive Order 13765]] *[[Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/10/12/presidential-executive-order-promoting-healthcare-choice-and-competition Presidential Executive Order Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition Across the United States], The White House (October 12, 2017) *[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/10/12/remarks-president-trump-signing-executive-order-promoting-healthcare Remarks by President Trump at Signing of Executive Order Promoting Healthcare Choice and Competition], The White House (October 12, 2017)
{{Trump executive actions}}

/* Look-a-likes */
revision.text:
{{short description|United States healthcare designation}} A '''Federally Qualified Health Center''' ('''FQHC''') is a reimbursement designation from the [[Bureau of Primary Health Care]] and the [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services]] of the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]]. This designation is significant for several health programs funded under the [[Health Center Consolidation Act]] (Section 330 of the [[Public Health Service Act]]).
FQHC is a community-based organization that provides comprehensive [[primary care]] and [[preventive care]], including [[health]], [[Oral hygiene|oral]], and [[mental health]]/[[substance abuse]] services to persons of all ages, regardless of their ability to pay or [[Health insurance in the United States|health insurance status]]. Thus, they are a critical component of the health care safety net.<ref name=Doty_et_al-2010>{{cite web|title=Enhancing the Capacity of Community Health Centers to Achieve High Performance|url=http://www.commonwealthfund.org/Publications/Fund-Reports/2010/May/Enhancing-the-Capacity-of-Community-Health-Centers-to-Achieve-High-Performance.aspx?page=all|publisher=The Commonwealth Fund|author=Michelle M. Doty|author2=Melinda K. Abrams |author3=Susan E. Hernandez |author4=Kristof Stremikis |author5=Anne C. Beal |date=May 2010}}</ref> FQHCs are called Community/Migrant Health Centers (C/MHC), Community Health Centers (CHC), and 330 Funded Clinics. FQHCs are automatically designated as [[Healthcare shortage area|health professional shortage facilities]].
==Funded programs== Health programs funded include:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bphc.hrsa.gov/about/|title=About the Health Center Program|website=bphc.hrsa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref>
*[[Community health centers in the United States|Community Health Centers]] which serve a variety of federally designated [[Healthcare shortage areas|Medically Underserved Area/Populations]] (MUA or MUP). *Migrant Health Centers which provide culturally competent and primary preventive medical care to migrant and seasonal agricultural workers,<ref name=specialpopulations/> *Health Care for the Homeless Programs which reach out to homeless individuals and families and provide primary and preventive care and substance abuse services,<ref name=specialpopulations/> and *Public Housing Primary Care Programs that serve residents of public housing and are located in or adjacent to the communities they serve.<ref name=specialpopulations/>
==Leadership== FQHCs operate under a consumer Board of Directors governance structure and function under the supervision of the [[Health Resources and Services Administration]] (HRSA), which is part of the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] (HHS). FQHCs were originally meant to provide comprehensive health services to the medically underserved to reduce the patient load on hospital [[emergency room]]s.
Their mission has changed since their founding. Their mission now is to enhance primary care services in underserved urban and rural communities.<ref name=cms201111>{{cite web|title=Federally Qualified Health Center|url=https://www.cms.gov/site-search/search-results.html?q=federally%20qualified%20health%20centers%20medicare|publisher=Department of Health and Human Services. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.|date=November 2011}}</ref> In particular, they serve [[Health insurance coverage in the United States|underserved, underinsured, and uninsured Americans]], including [[migrant worker]]s and non-[[Citizenship in the United States|U.S. citizens]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://bphc.hrsa.gov/programrequirements/pdf/healthcentercompliancemanual.pdf|title=Health Center Program Compliance Manual|last=|first=|date=2017|website=bphc.hrsa.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref>
FQHCs provide their services to all persons regardless of ability to pay, and charge for services on a community board approved [[Sliding scale fees|sliding-fee scale]] that is based on patients' family income and size. FQHCs must comply with Section 330 program requirements.<ref name=":0" />
In return for serving all patients regardless of ability to pay, the centers receive from the Federal government cash grant, cost-based reimbursement for their Medicaid patients, and malpractice coverage under the [[Federal Tort Claims Act]] (FTCA).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bphc.hrsa.gov/ftca/about/index.html|title=About the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA)|website=bphc.hrsa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref>
==Look-Alikes== The government also designates a category of health centers as "FQHC Look-Alikes." These health centers do not receive grants under Section 330 but are determined by the Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) to meet the requirements for receiving a grant based on the Health Resources and Services Administration recommendations.<ref name=cms201111/> Also, FQHC Look-Alikes receive cost-based reimbursement for their Medicaid services, but do not receive malpractice coverage under FTCA or a cash grant. Look-Alikes also qualify as health professional shortage areas (HPSA) automatically.
==Services under Medicare== FQHC benefit under [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]] became effective October 1, 1991, when Section 1861(aa) of the [[Social Security Act]] was amended by Section 4161 of the [[Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990]].<ref name=cms201111/> FQHCs provide Medicare beneficiaries with preventive primary health services such as immunizations, visual acuity and hearing screenings, and prenatal and post-partum care.<ref name=cms201111/> However, eyeglasses, hearing aids, and preventive dental services are not covered under the FQHC preventive primary services. A FQHC [[Prospective payment system|Prospective Payment System]] (PPS) was scheduled to be implemented in 2014.<ref name=cms201111/> The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) mandates that the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) collect and analyze health services data prior to developing and implementing the new payment system. This requires that the appropriate revenue code and [[Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System]] (HCPCS) code be listed with each service provided.<ref name=cms201111/> Currently,{{when|date=May 2017}} Medicare pays FQHC directly based on an all-inclusive per visit payment.<ref name=cms201111/>
==Advanced Primary Care Practice demonstration project== In June 2011, the Department of Health and Human Services announced the Federally Qualified Health Center Advanced Primary Care Practice (FQHC APCP) demonstration project.<ref name=hhs20110606a> {{cite web |title= New Affordable Care Act support to improve care coordination for nearly 200,000 people with Medicare |url= https://www.hhs.gov/news/press/2011pres/06/20110606a.html |publisher= Department of Health and Human Services |date=June 2011 }}</ref> This demonstration project is conducted under the authority of Section 1115A of the Social Security Act, which was added by section 3021 of the ACA and establishes the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (Innovation Center).<ref name=CMS1230557> {{cite web |title= Medicare Demonstrations: FQHC APCP FAQs. |url= https://www.cms.gov/demoprojectsevalrpts/md/itemdetail.asp?itemid=CMS1230557 |publisher= Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services }}</ref> The CMS and Innovation Center in partnership with HRSA will operate the demonstration.<ref name=cms201111/><ref name=CMS1230557/> This initiative was designed to evaluate the impact of the advanced primary care practice (APCP) model, also referred to as the [[Patient centered medical home|patient-centered medical home]] (PCMH) on improving health, quality of care and lowering the cost of care provided to Medicare beneficiaries.<ref name=cms201111/><ref name=CMS1230557/> The ACA will pay an estimated $42 million over three years (November 1, 2011 to October 31, 2014) to 500 FQHCs to coordinate care for 195,000 Medicare patients.<ref name=cms201111/><ref name=hhs20110606a/><ref name=CMS1230557/> Participating FQHCs agree to adopt care coordination practices set by the [[National Committee for Quality Assurance]] (NCQA) and are expected to achieve Level 3 patient-centered medical home recognition.<ref name=cms201111/><ref name=hhs20110606a/>
President Bush launched the [[Health Centers Initiative]] to significantly increase access to primary health care services in 1,200 communities through new or expanded health center sites. Between 2001 and 2006, the number of patients treated at health centers increased by over 4.7 million, representing a nearly 50 percent increase in just five years. In 2006 the number of patients served topped the 15 million mark for the first time.{{Citation needed|date=January 2016}}
Throughout the United States there are over 1,000 health centers that operate approximately 6,000 sites.<ref name=Doty_et_al-2010/> In 2010, the health centers served an estimated 20 million patients.<ref name=specialpopulations> {{cite web |title= Special Populations |url= http://bphc.hrsa.gov/about/specialpopulations/index.html |publisher= Department of Health and Human Services. Health Resources and Services Administration |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112130013/http://bphc.hrsa.gov/about/specialpopulations/index.html }}</ref> The data collected via the Uniform Data System (UDS) reports that of those patients served, 62 percent were members of a racial or ethnic minority (predominantly Hispanic), 93 percent lived at or below 200 percent of the federal poverty level, 72 percent lived at or below 100 percent of the federal poverty level, and 38 percent were uninsured.<ref> {{cite web |title= Health Center Data |url= http://bphc.hrsa.gov/healthcenterdatastatistics/index.html |publisher= Department of Health and Human Services. Health Resources and Services Administration }}</ref> In particular, during 2010 health centers served 862,775 migrant and seasonal farm workers and their families; more than 1 million individuals experiencing homelessness; and 172,731 residents of public housing.<ref name=specialpopulations/>
==Impact of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act== The health center program's annual federal funding has grown from $1.16 billion in fiscal year 2001 to $1.99 billion in fiscal year 2007. The passage of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] (ACA) in March 2010 resulted in provisions that increased federal funding to FQHCs to help them meet the anticipated health care demand of millions of Americans who will gain health care coverage as result of the health reform law.<ref name=kff201104>{{cite web|title=Summary of New Health Reform Law|url=http://www.kff.org/healthreform/8061.cfm|publisher=The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation|date=April 2011}}</ref> The ACA set aside $11 billion for community health centers over a period of five years to meet this goal.<ref name=kff201104/>
==Total centers by location== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:right" |+ FQHCs in 2016<ref>{{cite web|title=Number of Federally-Funded Federally Qualified Health Centers, 2016|url=http://www.statehealthfacts.org/comparetable.jsp?ind=424&cat=8&sub=99&yr=138&typ=1&sort=a|publisher=The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation}}</ref> |- !scope="col"|State or Territory !scope="col"|FQHCs |- |{{rh}}|Alabama || 14 |- |{{rh}}|Alaska|| 28 |- |{{rh}}|American Samoa|| 1 |- |{{rh}}|Arizona|| 21 |- |{{rh}}|Arkansas || 12 |- |{{rh}}|California || 176 |- |{{rh}}|Colorado || 20 |- |{{rh}}|Connecticut || 16 |- |{{rh}}|Delaware || 3 |- |{{rh}}|District of Columbia || 8 |- |{{rh}}|Fed. States of Micronesia|| 3 |- |{{rh}}|Florida || 48 |- |{{rh}}|Georgia || 35 |- |{{rh}}|Guam || 1 |- |{{rh}}|Hawaii || 14 |- |{{rh}}|Idaho || 14 |- |{{rh}}|Illinois || 45 |- |{{rh}}|Indiana || 25 |- |{{rh}}|Iowa || 14 |- |{{rh}}|Kansas|| 18 |- |{{rh}}|Kentucky || 23 |- |{{rh}}|Louisiana || 34 |- |{{rh}}|Maine || 18 |- |{{rh}}|Marshall Islands|| 1 |- |{{rh}}|Maryland|| 17 |- |{{rh}}|Massachusetts|| 39 |- |{{rh}}|Michigan || 39 |- |{{rh}}|Minnesota || 16 |- |{{rh}}|Mississippi || 21 |- |{{rh}}|Missouri || 28 |- |{{rh}}|Montana|| 17 |- |{{rh}}|Nebraska || 7 |- |{{rh}}|Nevada || 5 |- |{{rh}}|New Hampshire || 11 |- |{{rh}}|New Jersey || 23 |- |{{rh}}|New Mexico|| 17 |- |{{rh}}|New York || 65 |- |{{rh}}|Northern Marianas || 1 |- |{{rh}}|North Carolina || 38 |- |{{rh}}|North Dakota || 4 |- |{{rh}}|Ohio || 45 |- |{{rh}}|Oklahoma || 20 |- |{{rh}}|Oregon || 31 |- |{{rh}}|Pennsylvania || 44 |- |{{rh}}|Puerto Rico || 20 |- |{{rh}}|Republic of Palau|| 1 |- |{{rh}}|Rhode Island || 8 |- |{{rh}}|South Carolina || 22 |- |{{rh}}|South Dakota || 5 |- |{{rh}}|Tennessee || 29 |- |{{rh}}|Texas || 73 |- |{{rh}}|Utah|| 13 |- |{{rh}}|Vermont || 11 |- |{{rh}}|Virgin Islands || 2 |- |{{rh}}|Virginia|| 26 |- |{{rh}}|Washington || 27 |- |{{rh}}|West Virginia || 27 |- |{{rh}}|Wisconsin || 17 |- |{{rh}}|Wyoming || 6 |- class="sortbottom" |{{rh}}|Total || 1,367 |}
