revision.text:
[[File:Emeline Roberts Jones.jpg|thumb|[[Emeline Roberts Jones]].]] There is a long history of '''women in dentistry'''.
==Timeline== ===16th century=== * Unknown, 16th century: In an early copper engraving by [[Lucas Van Leyden]], a traveling dentist can be seen along with a woman acting as his assistant.<ref name="smile">{{cite web|url=http://thesmilecenterusa.com/blog/i-am-woman-hear-us-roar-and-see-us-do-teeth/#more-165 |title= I Am Woman…Hear Us Roar…and See Us Do Teeth! |publisher=thesmilecenterusa.com/ |date=March 1, 2013 |accessdate=May 29, 2013}}</ref>
===19th century=== * 1814: [[Josephine Serre]] became the first dentist to receive a dentistry degree from the [[University of Tartu]].<ref>The National Archives of Estonia. Serre, J, student file nr EAA.402.2.23142</ref> Her daughter [[Marie-Louis Serre]] graduated with a dentistry degree in 1829 from the same university.<ref>The National Archives of Estonia. Serre, Marie Louis student file nr. EAA.402.2.23143</ref> * 1852: [[Amalia Assur]] became the first female dentist in Sweden; she was given special permission from the [[:sv:Medicinalstyrelsen|Royal Board of Health]] (''Kongl. Sundhetskollegiets'') to practice independently as a dentist, despite the fact that the profession was not legally opened to women in Sweden before 1861.<ref name="smile"/> * 1855: [[Emeline Roberts Jones]] became the first woman to practice [[dentistry]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cwhf.org/inductees/science-health/emeline-roberts-jones |title=Emeline Roberts Jones | Connecticut Women's Hall of Fame |publisher=Cwhf.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> She married the dentist Daniel Jones when she was a teenager, and became his assistant in 1855.<ref name="wustl1">{{cite web|url=http://beckerexhibits.wustl.edu/mowihsp/health/womenindentistry.htm |title=Missouri Women in the Health Sciences - Health Professions - "Women in Dentistry" by E.N. King |publisher=Beckerexhibits.wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1866: [[Rosalie Fougelberg]] received a royal dispensation from Swedish King [[Charles XV]] and thus became the first woman in Sweden to officially practice dentistry since the profession had been legally opened to both genders in 1861.<ref name="smile"/> * 1866: [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] became the first woman to graduate from a dental college ([[Ohio College of Dental Surgery|Ohio Dental College]]).<ref name="wustl1"/> * 1869: [[Henriette Hirschfeld-Tiburtius]], born in Germany, became the first woman to take a full college course in dentistry, as [[Lucy Hobbs Taylor]] received credit for her time in dental practice before attending dental college.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.cda.org/page/Library/cda_member/pubs/journal/jour0602/hyson.html |title=June 2002 CDA Journal - Feature Article, Copyright 2002 Journal of the California Dental Association |publisher=Cda.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> She graduated from the [[Pennsylvania College of Dental Surgery]] in 1869.<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YhUxAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA1064&lpg=PA1064&dq=henriette+hirschfeld+dentist&source=bl&ots=JRHKuhDbv3&sig=hEpKkKs75oz0AezjhLCWpB41rwY&hl=en&ei=ZQh1Tua-CqLL0QGGu-XCDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Dental cosmos - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Henry Drummond. |url=http://digicoll.library.wisc.edu/cgi-bin/History/History-idx?type=HTML&rgn=div1&byte=323551095 |title=History: Madison : a model city: Browse Text |publisher=Digicoll.library.wisc.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1874: Fanny A. Rambarger became the second American woman to earn the degree of Doctor of Dental Surgery in 1874, when she graduated from the [[Pennsylvania College of Dental Surgery]]. She worked in Philadelphia and limited her practice to women and children only.<ref name="wustl1"/> * 1881: [[Margaret Caro]] became the first woman to be listed on the Dentists' Register of New Zealand.<ref name="DNZB Caro">{{DNZB|title=Margaret Caro|first= Mary Louise|last= Ormsby|id=2c8|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> * 1886: Margarita Chorné y Salazar became the first female dentist in Mexico.<ref name="smile"/> * 1890: [[Ida Gray|Ida Gray Rollins]] became the first African-American woman to earn a dental degree in the United States, which she earned from the [[University of Michigan]].<ref name="autogenerated1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourweekly.com/los-angeles/black-history-fact-week-ida-gray-nelson-rollins |title=Black History Fact of the Week: Ida Gray Nelson Rollins | Our Weekly - African American News | Black News | Black Entertainment | Black America |publisher=Our Weekly |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1892: The Women's Dental Association of the U.S. was founded in 1892 by [[Mary Stillwell-Kuesel]] with 12 charter members.<ref name="federationwomendentists">{{cite web|author=unknown|url=http://www.aawd.org/?page=HistoryofAAWD|title=History of AAWD |publisher=American Association of Women Dentists |accessdate=May 7, 2013}}</ref> * 1895: [[Lilian Lindsay]] became the first licensed female dentist in Britain.<ref name="smile"/> * 1898: [[Emma Gaudreau Casgrain]] became the first licensed female dentist in Canada.<ref name="smile"/>
===20th century=== * 1907: Frances Dorothy Gray became Australia’s first female Bachelor of Dental Science graduate from the Australian College of Dentistry, University of Melbourne, in 1907.<ref name="smile"/> * 1920: Maude Tanner became the first recorded female delegate to the [[American Dental Association]].<ref name="jdentaled1">{{cite journal|author=Patricia Blanton |url=http://www.jdentaled.org/content/70/11_suppl/38.full |title=Women in Dentistry: Negotiating the Move to Leadership |publisher= American Dental Education Association |journal=Journal of Dental Education |date=2006-11-01 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1921: During the annual meeting of the [[American Dental Association]] (ADA), 12 female dentists met in Milwaukee and formed the Federation of American Women Dentists, now known as the [[American Association of Women Dentists]] (AAWD). AAWD's first president, M. Evangeline Jordan, was one of the first to limit her practice to children and was a founder of [[pedodontics]]. She graduated from the [[University of California School of Dentistry]] in 1898.<ref name="federationwomendentists"/> * 1923: Anita Martin became the first woman inducted into the American dental honor society [[Omicron Kappa Upsilon]].<ref name="jdentaled1"/> * 1946: Lilian Lindsay became the first female president of the [[British Dental Association]].<ref name="smile"/> * 1951: Helen E. Myers of Lancaster, Pa., a 1941 graduate of Temple University, was commissioned as the U.S. [[Army Medical Department (United States)#Dental Corps .28DC.29|Army Dental Corps]]’ first female dental officer in 1951.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> *1967: [[Badri Teymourtash]] became the first female dean of a dental school in Iran([[Mashhad University of Medical Sciences]], School of dentistry). She had assisted in founding that school in 1965. Also, she was the first female dentist in Iran.<ref>{{ Mckenzie, T. (2014). WOMEN'S WORTH, PRICELESS. AuthorHouse. ISBN 978-1-4907-4707-1. Retrieved 20 November 2014.}}</ref> * 1975: On July 1, 1975, [[Jeanne Sinkford]] became the first female dean of an American dental school when she was appointed the dean of [[Howard University]], School of Dentistry.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> * 1977: The American Association of Dental Schools (founded in 1923 and renamed the [[American Dental Education Association]] in 2000) had Nancy Goorey as its first female president in 1977.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://selaminternational.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=31&Itemid=52 |title=SELAM International |publisher=SELAM International |date=2007-01-12 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1988: In 1988, the [[American Student Dental Association]] elected its first female president, N. Gail McLaurin of the Medical University of South Carolina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bu.edu/dental/asda/history.html |title=History » Dental School | Boston University |publisher=Boston University |date=1970-10-16 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 1991: Geraldine Morrow became the first female president of the [[American Dental Association]].<ref>[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-9515985.html American Dental Association elects first woman president. (Geraldine T. Morrow) - Search results from HighBeam Research<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * 1997: Hazel J. Harper became the first female president of the [American] [[National Dental Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cda.org/library/cda_member/pubs/journal/jour0602/hyson.html |title=June 2002 CDA Journal - Feature Article, Copyright 2002 Journal of the California Dental Association |publisher=California Dental Association |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F2xKSaWXOTwC&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=%22national+dental+association%22+%22first+woman%22&source=bl&ots=O9SpDqraY1&sig=WpFWGMIZAzyOsRjaRT7waJR9rMU&hl=en&ei=8o53TqynK6Lm0QHAwfjADQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22national%20dental%20association%22%20%22first%20woman%22&f=false |title=Ebony - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref>
===21st century=== * 2001: Marjorie Jeffcoat became the first female editor of [[The Journal of the American Dental Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jada.ada.org/content/132/9/1216.full |title=Dr. Marjorie K. Jeffcoat to become JADA editor |publisher=Jada.ada.org |date=2001-09-01 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 2003: Rear Admiral [[Carol I. Turner]] became the first female Chief of the U.S. [[Navy Dental Corps]].<ref name="jdentaled1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Dan Petty |url=http://www.navy.mil/navydata/bios/navybio.asp?bioID=287 |title=Leadership Biographies |publisher=Navy.mil |date=2008-09-04 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 2004: Sandra Madison, of Asheville, N.C., was elected as the first female president of the [[American Association of Endodontists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dentistryiq.com/index/display/article-display/206925/articles/dental-office/online-stories/dr-sandra-madison-elected-president-of-american-association-of-endodontists.html |title=Dr. Sandra Madison elected president of American Association of Endodontists |publisher=DentistryIQ |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 2005: [[Michele Aerden]] became the first female president of the [[FDI World Dental Federation]]. * 2007: Laura Kelly became the first female president of the [[American Academy of Cosmetic Dentistry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lkdentalstudio.com/team/LauraKelly.html |title=Meet the A Team at LK Dental Studio | Laura Kelly | President, LK Dental Studio |publisher=Lkdentalstudio.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 2008: Beverly Largent, a pediatric dentist from Paducah, Ky., became the first female president of the [[American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://capitolwords.org/date/2008/06/04/E1138-3_tribute-to-beverly-largent/ |title=Tribute To Beverly Largent |publisher=Capitol Words, A project of The [[Sunlight Foundation]] |date=June 4, 2008 |accessdate=May 7, 2013}}</ref> * 2008: Valerie Murrah became the first female president of the [[American Academy of Oral and Maxillofacial Pathology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uncnews.unc.edu/content/view/1429/138/ |title=UNC News - Murrah installed as first female president of dental specialty academy |publisher=Uncnews.unc.edu |date=2008-07-30 |accessdate=2012-08-04}}</ref> * 2008: Paula Jones became the first female president of the [[Academy of General Dentistry]].<ref name="Women Advancing Dentistry">{{cite web|url=http://www.dentalaegis.com/special-issues/AAWD/2009/12/women-advancing-dentistry |title=Women Advancing Dentistry |publisher=AEGIS Communications |date=2009 |accessdate=May 29, 2013}}</ref> * 2008: Deborah Stymiest of Fredericton was elected as the first female president of the [[Canadian Dental Association]].<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.jcda.ca/article/b73 |title=CDA Award Winners |website=jcda.ca|publisher=Canadian Dental Association|issn=1488-2159|date=May 31, 2011 |accessdate=May 29, 2013}}</ref> * 2008: Susan Bordenave-Bishop became the first female president of the [[Academy of Dentistry International]].<ref name="Women Advancing Dentistry"/> * 2009: Kathleen T. O'Loughlin, of Medford, Mass., became the first female executive director of the [[American Dental Association]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ada.org/3266.aspx|title=Dr. Kathleen O'Loughlin Named American Dental Association Executive Director |publisher=American Dental Association |date=May 5, 2009|accessdate=May 7, 2013}}</ref> * 2013: Gayle Glenn was elected as the first female president of the [[American Association of Orthodontists]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dentistrytoday.com/industry-news/9237-new-officers-elected-new-trustee-installed-at-american-association-of-orthodontists|title=New Officers Elected, New Trustee Installed At American Association Of Orthodontists |publisher=Dentistry Today |date=May 16, 2013|accessdate=June 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asdablog.com/orthodontists-to-install-first-female-president/|title=Orthodontists to install first female president|publisher=www.asdablog.com |date=March 1, 2013|accessdate=June 28, 2013}}</ref>
